awd_titl_txt: RUI: Time-independent excited state methods for computational screening of photoactive materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Tim Kowalczyk of Western Washington University is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry to develop simulations that rapidly predict the visible-light absorption, energy conversion, and emission capabilities of organic materials. In these materials, the redirection of light energy into a flow of electrons forms the basis of emerging technologies including flexible solar cells, low-toxicity flow batteries, and noninvasive light-based therapies for the treatment of certain cancers. The research supported by this award fills a critical gap in existing methodology to enable fast computational screening of organic materials according to their photoactivity. Kowalczyk mentors a predominantly undergraduate team of student researchers in the development and application of these simulations to understand the behavior of light-absorbing materials both in isolation and in complex molecular environments. These rapid screening simulations are paired with high-accuracy modeling to uncover the details of how specialized organic dyes use the energy in light to produce the reactive oxygen species that destroy diseased tissue in photodynamic cancer therapy. Kowalczyk is linking demonstrations of simulations developed in this award to a program of undergraduate student-led energy literacy outreach in conjunction with WWU's Institute for Energy Studies.

Kowalczyk and coworkers are pursuing rapid simulation strategies for photoactive materials screening through the development, benchmarking assessment, and application of time-independent excited state methods within the density-functional tight-binding (DFTB) formalism. This research seeks to transform the nascent time-independent DFTB (TI-DFTB) approach into a practical, computationally efficient strategy for photoactive materials screening as well as for multi-scale excited-state simulations in condensed phases. The TI-DFTB molecular dynamics simulations developed in this award enable efficient conformational sampling on excited-state potential energy surfaces with a self-consistent, quantum mechanical treatment of the molecular environment. Simple chemical descriptors are extracted from TI-DFTB excited-state simulations to characterize the photosensitization of singlet oxygen by a range of organic chromophores. This award supports the training and mentoring of a diverse group of undergraduate and masters-level research students at a primarily undergraduate institution.

por.por_cntn:
Organic molecules that absorb visible light, also known as chromophores, can be tuned through direct modification of the chemical structure as well as through subtle changes to their local environment. The ability to predict and control how energy is transferred in these chromophores drives progress in the development of technologies ranging from organic solar cells and photoswitches to photodynamic therapies for certain cancers. This project has delivered a new suite of tools for predicting the key wavelengths of light absorbed by organic chromophores. The new tools belong to a family of approximate electronic structure methods called density functional tight-binding (DFTB). In contrast to the widely employed time-dependent linear response approaches often used for these predictions, our time-independent (TI) approach is by well-suited by construction to addressing charge transfer across a chromophore and offers easy access to excited-state properties such as optimized geometries, fluorescence wavelengths, and excited-state vibrational frequencies. Despite the more approximate nature of DFTB methods, we found that the TI-DFTB approach to excited states is well-suited to a range of problems where its computational efficiency may make it a preferred choice for virtual screening of excited state properties.

Outcomes reflecting the intellectual merit of the project center on the advantages of TI-DFTB's rapid access to information about the lowest singlet excited state. For example, we employed TI-DFTB methods in a computational study of solar thermal fuels, organic photoswitches that store solar energy through a molecular twist and can then be triggered to release it by untwisting. In this study, we found that a TI-DFTB approach can rank the members of a set of chemically related solar thermal fuels by excitation energy with sufficient accuracy to justify its use as an initial virtual screening stage for identifying promising solar thermal fuel candidate materials. Rapid prediction of excited-state properties beyond the energy was also a priority. We used TI-DFTB to model how the presence of solvent molecules shifts an organic chromophore's emission wavelength (solvatochromic shift). Here we found that the method can report on the convergence of solvatochromic shifts with inclusion of up to 2-3 solvent shells but suffers from convergence challenges at larger radii, opening an avenue for further exploration.

The TI-DFTB methods developed in this project can also improve our mechanistic understanding of photodynamic therapy agents. To demonstrate this concept, we used TI-DFTB excited-state molecular dynamics to simulate the photophysics of reactive singlet oxygen produced via visible-light irradiation of a member of the BODIPY family of chromophores. The study revealed sensitivity of certain excited-state transitions in the complex to the orientation of the oxygen molecule relative to the chromophore; computationally derived insights of this type complement experimental investigations of photodynamic therapy agents by providing atomic-level glimpses into excited-state processes that current characterization methods struggle to access, advancing the development of these agents. Our implementation of a method for computing transition dipole moments (TDMs) introduced a first-of-its-kind approach to the problem based on the use of so-called "corresponding orbitals" to overcome the challenge that the ground and excited state wavefunctions describing the electrons in these molecules are technically constructed from distinct sets of molecular orbitals in the TI-DFTB approach. Several collaborations with organic and organometallic synthetic chemists interested in photoactive materials afforded us opportunities to test and refine some of our excited-state models while they were under active development.

Broader impacts of the project include public availability of the new computational methods; training of undergraduates and visiting early-career scientists in sought-after technical and communication skills; strengthening of international collaboration with partners in Europe and Asia; and the development of an outreach program connecting high school students in the region with the breadth of energy science research happening at WWU. The source code for our completed TI-DFTB methods is publicly available and integrated into the open-source DFTB+ electronic structure program with documentation to introduce new users to the theory. The project supported first scientific research experiences for eight undergraduate students and the advanced training of four MS students. The Energy Ambassadors, an outreach program within the WWU Institute for Energy Studies, was launched alongside this project and engaged cohorts of 4-6 undergraduate summer researchers on energy-related projects with thoughtful discussions about effectively communicating their work, culminating in student-designed outreach activities for high school audiences. Collaborations with scientists at WWU and abroad introduced students to the interplay between theory and experiment in modern chemical research while revealing how cultural diversity can foster creativity and innovation in the sciences.
